title: Impetus
definition: A force that causes something to be done or to become more active.
example1: The high crime rate was the impetus for the hiring of one hundred new police officers in our city.
example2: In the film, the leading character’s need to rescue his son is the impetus that drives the movie’s plot.

title: Erroneous
definition: Make (someone) very weak and infirm.
example1: Despite the fact that you used an erroneous method to solve the problem, somehow you managed to arrive at the correct solution.
example2: She knew that the testimony was erroneous, but her attorney advised her to sign the transcript anyway.

title: Elucidate
definition: To make clear or easy to understand.
example1: To make life easy for my math students, I go out of my way to elucidate the complex problems before each test.
example2: The tutorial is designed to elucidate the basic steps of computer programming to novice programmers.

title: Contretemps
definition: A minor dispute or disagreement.
example1: The background to the contretemps was that Bartram, momentarily distracted during the phone interview.
example2: Well, resolving that contretemps will certainly make the world a better place.

title: Abscond
definition: Escape into hiding; to leave quickly and hide to avoid punishment
example1: Do you think he has plans to abscond with the stolen money?
example2: Unable to pay their rent, the tenants decided to abscond in the middle of the night.

title: Substratum
definition: A foundation or basis of something.
example1: There is a broad substratum of truth in her story.
example2: The paper was used as a substratum, prevent the writing from the marker soaking through to the table.

title: Precocious
definition: Having mature qualities at an unusually early age.
example1: I was a precocious child who at the age of four was already discussing the daily news with my parents.
example2: Because Jackson was eight years old, his precocious comments about the president surprised everyone.

title: Platitude
definition: Something that has been said so often that it is not interesting anymore.
example1: Because I have heard your platitude a hundred times, it means nothing to me now.
example2: Because my teacher felt my essay response was a boring platitude, she gave me a failing score on the paper.

title: Pertinent
definition: Relevant to a particular matter
example1: To ensure a prompt reply, please include all pertinent details in your email.
example2: With only a few minutes left in class, the professor quickly tried to answer the questions pertinent to today’s lecture.

title: Malleable
definition: Capable of being easily changed or influenced.
example1: When my uncle drinks a great deal, he is always quite malleable to suggestions.
example2: If you are too malleable, people will try and take advantage of you.

title: Incongruous
definition: Out of place; inconsistent or incompatible.
example1: How incongruous of a fat doctor telling me to lose weight!
example2: Working for a christian organization as an atheist is incongruous.

title: Despondent
definition: Very sad and without hope.
example1: Marilyn was despondent after her husband of fifty years died.
example2: Because I just won a huge lottery, I am no longer despondent about my financial concerns.

title: Debilitate
definition: Make (someone) very weak and infirm.
example1: Cancer can quickly debilitate an otherwise healthy person.
example2: n an effort to debilitate her attacker, she delivered a quick kick to the groin.

title: Belligerent
definition: Hostile; ready to fight.
example1: My brother was always belligerent and ready to fight.
example2: If you want to see a belligerent dog, you should attempt to take his food while he is eating it.

title: Ancillary
definition: In addition to the main unit, worker, or task.
example1: If we start the ancillary generators, we should have enough power to keep the main generator online.
example2: In addition to the main dining room, there are several ancillary restaurants on the cruise ship.

title: Contretemps
definition: A minor dispute or disagreement.
example1: Well, resolving that contretemps will certainly make the world a better place.
example2: The background to the contretemps was that Bartram, momentarily distracted during the phone interview.

title: Vociferous
definition: Making a loud outcry
example1: The protestors were vociferous as they screamed outside of the government building.
example2: My uncle is a vociferous man who loudly expresses his opinion on everything.

title: Repudiate
definition: To reject, refuse to support
example1: The company will repudiate any claims of negligence.
example2: Jill is going to repudiate the bill because it is incorrect.

title: Magnum Opus
definition: The greatest achievement of an artist or writer
synonyms: great work, masterpiece, piece de resistance
example1: Thus opens The Life of Mammals, Attenborough's new magnum opus for the BBC.
example2: The Gospel of John held a place close to his heart and his magisterial commentary on John remains perhaps his magnum opus.

title: Jubilant
definition: Filled with joy
example1: I am jubilant to learn that my sister is finally having a baby.
example2: Watching the ball drop on New Year's is always a jubilant moment.

title: Jettison
definition: To eliminate something
example1: In order to conserve fuel, the pilot was forced to jettison some of his passengers’ suitcases.
example2: Because the new stroller is not selling well, the company has decided to jettison it from their product line.

title: Fervour
definition: Intense and passionate feeling
example1: The terrorist’s fervor made him believe that giving his life for his cause was his purpose in life.
example2: The woman’s spiritual fervor led her to leave her husband and become a nun.

title: Dogmatic
definition: To strongly state unsupported opinions or beliefs as if they were absolute facts
example1: Because he refused to listen to others, everyone considered the politician to be too dogmatic.
example2: My teacher was dogmatic in her grading practices and would not even consider altering my grade!

title: Detritus
definition: Waste or debris of any kind
example1: All are made of detritus such as cans, fairy lights, plastic flowers and toys that Yore has found, had donated to him.
example2: There are ways to get rid of Christmas detritus in ways that help the environment.

title: Chicanery
definition: The use of trickery to achieve a political, financial, or legal purpose
example1: You can smell the chicanery from a dishonest politician.
example2: Instead of dealing with my lawyer's chicanery, I will hire another.

title: Cadence
definition: A consistent rhythm or beat
example1: We were happy when our fast-talking professor started to speak in a slow cadence we could understand.
example2: Sam’s songs have such a lively cadence that they are very popular in dance clubs.

title: Attrition
definition: A reduction or decrease in numbers, size, or strength
example1: As a result of teacher attrition, a lot of classrooms are overcrowded.
example2: The company president is using attrition to save money by not hiring new employees.

title: Antipathy
definition: A feeling of dislike
example1: The teenagers expressed their antipathy for the school by vandalizing the gym.
example2: Although the two countries disagree over nuclear weapons, they are united by their antipathy for the United States.

title: Abashed
definition: Make (someone) feel embarrassed, disconcerted, or ashamed.
example1: Perhaps slightly abashed by his own (entirely justified) boldness, Goldhill occasionally muzzles his own point.
example2: Were the Bush lawyers abashed? Not at all.

title: Vicarious
definition: Experienced or felt by watching, hearing about, or reading about someone else rather than by doing something yourself.
example1: My paralyzed uncle takes vicarious pride in his son’s running achievements.
example2: Since I have many food allergies, I tend to be a vicarious eater who enjoys food through the stories of others.

title: Stratagem
definition: A scheme or a clever plot, especially one used to outwit an opponent or achieve a goal.
example1: His chess stratagem was so good that he never lost a match.
example2: With the right stratagem, you can accomplish just about any goal.

title: Repudiation
definition: To reject; refuse to support.
example1: The company will repudiate any claims of negligence.
example2: During his next speech, the president will repudiate blame for the economic situation.

title: Pernicious
definition: Highly injurious or destructive.
example1: Because she hates me, my neighbor is always spreading pernicious lies about me.
example2: If you are going to behave in such a pernicious manner, I would prefer to not be around you.

title: Modus Operandi
definition: A particular way or method of doing something.
example1: Assuming that these conditions can be rigidly realized, we have the following very simple modus operandi.
example2: The modus operandi is briefly as follows. The position of the fracture is determined by electrical tests from both ends, with more or less accuracy, depending on the nature of the fracture, but with a probable error not exceeding a few miles.

title: Efficacy
definition: The power to produce a desired effect.
example1: The instructor’s efficacy was reduced by the lack of educational materials.
example2: Since I have never practiced yoga, I cannot speak on its efficacy to provide relaxation.

title: Surreptitious
definition: Something that is done in secret or that is kept quiet
example1: The dog has his surreptitious ways of stealing table scraps behind my back.
example2: It is difficult to live a surreptitious life in a house full of snoopy people.

title: Etymology
definition: The source of a word, or the study of the source of specific words.
example1: After a bit of research, I found the etymology associated with my name and discovered my name’s meaning.
example2: The etymology of most medical terms can be found in the Latin language.

title: Erroneous
definition: Something that is incorrect or in error
example1: If you have used erroneous statistics in your report, you will have to start over from the beginning.
example2: After he had spent every waking moment of the past few days researching the subject, he was understandably frustrated when he discovered that several of his sources contained erroneous information.

title: Copious
definition: Something of which there is a large amount
example1: To avoid having a hangover, do not drink a copious amount of alcohol.
example2: With your copious free time this week, you should be volunteer at the homeless shelter.

title: Auspicious
definition: Being a sign of future success; indicating a promising future
example1: His brilliant acceptance speech was an auspicious start to his political career.
example2: Since his father was a state judge, Henry was born with an auspicious legal career ahead of him.

title: Affable
definition: A person who is friendly or easy to talk to.
example1: People enjoy eating at that restaurant because the waitresses are always so affable.
example2: Although he looks great, I won’t approach him because I do not believe he is very affable.

title: Subservient
definition: Prepared to obey others unquestioningly.
example1: In the movie, you will play the role of a subservient son who never talks back to his father.
example2: The stuck-up singer believed everyone should be subservient to her.

title: Panoply
definition: A beautiful and striking set up, magnificent decor or clothing, or a protective covering.
example1: The designer’s exciting panoply of dresses won over the fashion critics.
example2: When the media arrived, the boastful world leader made sure they photographed his panoply of exotic cars.

title: Notwithstanding
definition: Despite or although.
example1: Partisanship notwithstanding, this was not lost on anyone.
example2: And notwithstanding our strong economy, a near record stockmarket and low unemployment, this is a time of war.

title: Libation
definition: A drink poured out as an offering to a deity.
example1: Unfortunately, I am not old enough to order a libation at the bar.
example2: After a rough day at work, I usually stop by a bar for a relaxing libation.

title: Inscrutable
definition: Impossible to understand or interpret.
example1: When Larry wrote the letter, he was so tired the writing was nearly inscrutable.
example2: Not even the leading experts in criminology could understand the killer’s inscrutable motives.

title: Indignant
definition: Feeling or showing anger because of something unjust.
example1: Rosa Parks was indignant when asked to give up her seat on a public bus so that a white man could sit down.
example2: However, they turned out to be adult incontinence pads, which King indignantly denied were his.

title: Inconclusive
definition: Something that did not produce clear results or that did not resolve a question or dispute.
example1: But, as in the US, scientists here have long regarded local and overseas trials as inconclusive and economically dubious.
example2: Just a regular, old, inconclusive replay.

title: Incomprehensible
definition: Something that cannot be explained or cannot be understood.
example1: Luke's homework was too incomprehensible for him.
example2: It's incomprehensible, but the tipster keeps doing it.

title: Facsimile
definition: An exact copy, especially of written or printed material.
example1: You might have heard of facsimile otherwise known as fax.
example2: A lavish facsimile was recently made of the most beautiful and famous manuscript of Chaucer's Canterbury Tales.

title: Balustrade
definition: Railing that is held up by supporting posts.
example1: Instead, there are walls on the sides and a balustrade in the front.
example2: Using this kind of balustrade can be a very attractive way to decorate any.

title: Oligopoly
definition: An economic market where there is limited competition.
example1: Although the uptake has been slow and print on the web is in danger of becoming controlled by an oligopoly of companies.
example2: Oligopoly structure An industry dominated by a small group of competitors.

title: Staunch
definition: Someone or something strong, loyal or well made.
example1: All states except Russia are staunch allies of the US.
example2: Despite his Evangelical convictions, Haweis remained a staunch churchman.

title: Remiss
definition: To be negligent or careless or not do something you should
example1: If I let you go without food, I would be remiss in my responsibilities as a parent.
example2: Because the elves were remiss in their toy making, Santa did not have enough gifts to fill his sleigh.

title: Meritorious
definition: Government or the holding of power by people selected according to merit.
example1: Lastly, they can be used to reward employees for particularly meritorious work.
example2: Of all his achievements, winning the gold medal was definitely his most meritorious.

title: Magnanimous
definition: Very generous or forgiving; unselfish
example1: Despite the slurs made against him by his opponent, the boxer was magnanimous enough to praise his competitor.
example2: Because she was kind and generous, the magnanimous queen was loved by all.

title: Elicit
definition: To draw out or bring forth
example1: The comedian hoped his jokes would elicit a great deal of laughter from the audience.
example2: The police chief hoped to elicit the truth about the missing evidence from the corrupt officer.

title: Burgeon
definition: Burgeon means to grow or blossom.
example1: As car prices go down, car dealers are expecting sales to burgeon.
example2: Because Janice is pregnant with triplets, everyone is expecting her stomach to burgeon quickly.

title: Behoove
definition: In an individual’s interest
example1: If you seriously want to get your driving permit, it would behoove you to start studying for the computer test.
example2: It would behoove my husband to take his medication as his doctor instructed.

title: Antiquated
definition: Something that is out of date, old or no longer useful.
example1: Why would such a young woman wear antiquated dresses that make her look like an old lady?
example2: The old mansion is overflowing with antiquated furnishings worth millions of dollars.

title: Hegemony
definition: Leadership or dominance of one group over another.
example1: The president of the company has hegemony over his employees.
example2: When the dictator was chased out of the country, his hegemony over the people came to an end.

title: Enigmatic
definition: Something that is like a puzzle or riddle that can’t be understood
example1: The enigmatic spy was not known to have any family or friends.
example2: When I was growing up, I viewed my father as an enigmatic man who rarely spent time with me.

title: Deluge
definition: A severe flood
example1: He received a deluge of post, most of it abusive.
example2: The deluge of data that practices have acquired is overwhelming.

title: Accoutrement
definition: An additional item of dress or equipment.
example1: They need the Internet, mobile phones, computers, and the other accoutrements of the modern age for the wealth they bring.
example2: She emerged from the kitchen with a tray laden with coffee and its accoutrements, a slice of pie and water.

title: Tumultuous
definition: Having great disturbance, uproar, chaos or noise
example1: His own solo spots were received with tumultuous applause.
example2: We marched into the town square to a tumultuous welcome.

title: Subterfuge
definition: A plan or action to hide what you’re doing
example1: When my girlfriend asks me, Does this make me look fat? I subterfuge by saying no.
example2: From now on, he will no longer subterfuge to his family and instead focus on living an honest lifestyle.

title: Stoicism
definition: One who is not moved by pain or pleasure
example1: I was enormously moved by the stoicism shown by our US colleagues.
example2: Because my sister keeps her feelings to herself, everyone considers her to be stoic.

title: Parlance
definition: A particular way of speaking or using words, especially a way common to those with a particular job or interest
example1: The two words ought to be interchangeable but in restaurant parlance it seems that pancakes can be thick or thin.
example2: In homicide parlance, the first 48 hours of an investigation are crucial.

title: Inebriated
definition: Drunk or intoxicated
example1: But even the company of an inebriated seaman would prove less infuriating.
example2: Everyone else followed in groups sorted on the basis of skill and level of inebriation.

title: Heinous
definition: Heinous is very evil or horrible
example1: Then I commited the heinous crime of deciding to swap from my debit to my credit card.
example2: For the right amount, the sleazy lawyer will represent even the most heinous criminals.

title: Exorbitant
definition: Something that is excessive or goes beyond reasonable
example1: Why travel far or pay exorbitant fees for acting classes?
example2: Why are we paying him an exorbitant sum of money to do nothing?

title: Congruent
definition: Something that agrees with or is in harmony with another.
example1: Use the conditions for congruent triangles in formal geometric proofs.
example2: This is also congruent with thinking reflected in the Disability Discrimination Act.

title: Coitus
definition: Sexual intercourse
example1: Quick coitus or slow? Flowers or footy games? Like everything else in life, it's all a question of perspective.
example2: During a moment of passion, both lovers were joined in a coitus.

title: Charcuterie
definition: Cold cooked meats.
example1: Some of the best charcuterie comes from this area, where wild pigs have gorged themselves on the fallen chestnuts.
example2: Try it with penne pasta with salmon in a creamy sauce, charcuterie or even pan fried venison.

title: Atrophy
definition: The weakening, loss, wasting away, break-down or growth halt of something such as a body part, plant, person, place or thing.
example1: Students who rely on the Internet for research purposes soon discover their manual research skills have begun to atrophy.
example2: The bullet in Jack's head is causing his brain to atrophy.

title: Asinine
definition: To be silly, stupid or ridiculous
example1: However, I did not expect such an asinine comment as I have to watch cyclists rather than the scenery.
example2: Allowing your children to smoke cigarettes is asinine.

title: Totalitarian
definition: A government where the ruler or ruling group has complete control
example1: What were the main features of totalitarian dictatorship in Nazi Germany?
example2: V for Vendetta is set in a London of the future, in a totalitarian state ruled over by a Chancellor (John Hurt).

title: Recapitulate
definition: To restate or briefly summarize what you have said or the information presented
example1: At the start of each class, the professor will recapitulate yesterday’s lecture.
example2: The president will recapitulate the main points of his speech before leaving the podium.

title: Pugilist
definition: One who fights with his fists; especially a professional prize fighter; a boxer
example1: Players can direct their pugilist's fists using the right analog stick.
example2: Williams is a fairly talented heavyweight boxer - he is arguably of the pugilist mold.

title: Preponderance
definition: Superiority in weight, force, importance, or influence
example1: The preponderance of medical research links the genetic mutation to the disorder.
example2: The restaurant ran out of food because it was not prepared for such a preponderance of customers on opening day.

title: Precocious
definition: A person who is more developed or more mature than expected for their age
example1: My precocious little girl thinks she knows everything there is to know about life.
example2: The precocious high school athlete played basketball like he was a paid professional.

title: Pejorative
definition: Expressing disapproval or belittling the importance of something
example1: Although the writer meant to be kind, his words implied a pejorative point of view.
example2: If you make pejorative remarks in front of your customers, it is highly likely they will not return to your business.

title: Myopic
definition: Unable to see distant objects unaided
example1: If you only question one race of people in your survey, your responses will be myopic.
example2: Asking for different opinions is one way to come up with a solution that is broad and not myopic.

title: Jurisprudence
definition: Jurisprudence is the legal system, or the theory and practice of the law
example1: It is worth notice- that practical jurisprudence has long engaged the American intellect with success.
example2: He is currently a teaching assistant on the undergraduate Jurisprudence course.

title: Inoculate
definition: To vaccinate someone against a disease.
example1: Your G.P. can also inoculate but may take a while to get to get the vaccine in.
example2: Did you know that bees have an ephemeral 5 week lifespan?

title: Hubris
definition: Arrogance or excessive pride
example1: The leader of the cult had so much hubris he believed the government would never be able to capture him.
example2: Don’t let your hubris cost you friends!

title: Gentrification
definition: Upgrading of deteriorated urban property by middle-class or affluent people
example1: There has been gentrification and some locals don't like their road being closed during the festival.
example2: With prices rising, many new residents are making a bet that downtown will continue to gentrify.

title: Erudite
definition: Someone who has wide range of knowledge and is well-read
example1: As a result of having studied abroad several years, Helen has become quite erudite on the subject of art history.
example2: Because I am failing calculus, I am in search of the most erudite calculus tutor I can find.

title: Epicurean
definition: A person devoted to sensual enjoyment, especially that derived from fine food and drink.
example1: He indulged himself fully in the epicurean lifestyle to which he had become accustomed over the years.
example2: Our chefs prepare a range of delicious epicurean delights for the patrons who partake of our menu

title: Ephemeral
definition: Something that has a very short lifespan or lasts for a very short time
example1: An ephemeral stay in the waiting room was a nice treat compared to my usual long waits.
example2: Did you know that bees have an ephemeral 5 week lifespan?

title: Disingenuous
definition: Pretending one knows less than one actually does
example1: The detective was a disingenuous man who often played dumb to trick others into confessing.
example2: Do not allow disingenuous people to deceive you to the point where you do something stupid!

title: Copacetic
definition: Copacetic is perfectly satisfactory or in perfect order.
example1: All was calm and copacetic in the suburbs.
example2: It was his philosophy that every day, in every way, was copacetic.

title: Conciliatory
definition: Something done to reconcile or to try to make someone feel better and more pacified
example1: Don’t think you are going to appease me with your conciliatory attitude!
example2: As the middle sister, behaving in a conciliatory manner came natural to her.

title: Autodidactic
definition: A person who is self-educated
example1: It is a remarkable acknowledgement for an autodidact who left school after failing year 10
example2: The 39-year-old comedian and autodidact more or less disappeared from view five years ago.

title: Antiquity
definition: The ancient past, especially the period of classical and other human civilizations before the Middle Ages.
example1: In antiquity yeast was made from sour dough, which was taken from last year 's crop.
example2: The philosophers of late antiquity have sometimes appeared to be estranged from society.

title: Undulate
definition: Move with a smooth wave-like motion.
example1: Effortlessly, the dolphin seemed to undulate in the water.
example2: It is fun to watch the ocean waters undulate beneath our glass-bottom boat.

title: Pertinent
definition: Something that has a logical connection to the current subject.
example1: The surgeon will require all of the pertinent equipment to perform the heart surgery.
example2: If you perform a Google search, you will easily find a list of articles pertinent to the subject you were discussing.

title: Pejorative
definition: Expressing disapproval or belittling the importance of something
example1: Although the writer meant to be kind, his words implied a pejorative point of view.
example2: If you make pejorative remarks in front of your customers, it is highly likely they will not return to your business.

title: Illustrious
definition: Well known, respected, and admired for past achievements
example1: Because Sarah has never made a grade lower than an A, her teachers voted her the most illustrious member of the senior class.
example2: As a member of an illustrious family of doctors, John is considered to be one of the city’s most eligible bachelors.

title: Diatribe
definition: Abusive speech or piece of writing
example1: The cult leader used religion to make a diatribe against the government.
example2: Because Sheila was unhappy with the administration, she launched a lengthy diatribe against the board during lunch.

title: Despotism
definition: The exercise of absolute power, especially in a cruel and oppressive way.
example1: Political despotism is perfectly compatible with the existence of a reasonably market economy.
example2: A Chinese mandarin is as much the tool and creature of a despotism as the humblest cultivator.

title: Vindicate
definition: To clear someone of criticism or blame.
example1: You can vindicate your claim to this property by showing us the original deed.
example2: Don’t even try to use your charm and good looks to vindicate your obnoxious behavior last night.

title: Reprehensible
definition: Highly unacceptable action; deserving severe disapproval or criticism
example1: There is nothing reprehensible about loving your goldfish more than your dogs.
example2: Your conduct is reprehensible and will not be tolerated!

title: Nominal
definition: Something that has almost no value or something that exists in name only
example1: Despite his immense wealth, Frank is a selfish man who gives a nominal amount to charities each year.
example2: With my coupons, my groceries cost me a nominal amount this week.

title: Nepotism
definition: Giving relatives special treatment, especially in the workplace.
example1: Since George is an idiot everyone knows his father hired him because of nepotism.
example2: Hiring your daughter to work at your store is surefire nepotism.

title: Licentious
definition: Lacking moral discipline or ignoring legal restraint, especially in sexual conduct
example1: Since I know Megan has a reputation for being licentious, I never let her get too close to my husband.
example2: Even before she became a prostitute, Hazel was considered a licentious woman who lacked morals.

title: Liberality
definition: Willing to respect or accept behaviour or opinions different from one's own; open to new ideas.
example1: The liberality of the people was overwhelmingly more than could ever have been expected.
example2: He was at once a man of fixed belief and large appreciation, so that his dogmatism and his liberality sometimes came into collision.

title: Lackadaisical
definition: Showing lack of interest or spirit
example1: It was the previous landlord who had accepted the lackadaisical approach by the tenant.
example2: Mary is so lackadaisical she will not get out of bed most mornings.

title: Fallacious
definition: Containing a mistake, not true or accurate
example1: The following is a fallacious proof that all cows in a field are the same color.
example2: Mr Howard declared the comparison fallacious.

title: Doxology
definition: A Christian song of praise which is sung as part of a worship service.
example1: To David; here the doxology is peculiar, Blessed be Jehovah God of Israel from everlasting and to everlasting.
example2: Romans 11:36 is a great doxology given to God.

title: Aphorism
definition: Brief sentence or phrase that expresses an opinion or a statement.
example1: He often begins an aphorism with a quoted passage.
example2: It proves the old aphorism that if something looks too good to be true then it probably is.

title: Altruism
definition: The principle or practice of concern for the welfare of others.
example1: Should we assume that people are motivated by altruism or self-interest?
example2: My altruistic daughter gave all her allowance to the homeless man on the corner.

title: Allegory
definition: A story, poem, or picture which can be interpreted to reveal a hidden meaning, typically a moral or political one.
example1: An example of allegory would be Aesop's Fables.
example2: The Colnaghi picture depicts an allegory of sin and redemption.

title: Prognosticate
definition: To predict something or at least hint at what will happen in the future.
example1: Today your doctor will be performing your annual physical in order to prognosticate your future health.
example2: Every year, many foolish people pay fortunetellers to prognosticate their futures.

title: Fortuitous
definition: Happening by chance; accidental
example1: Mark proved to be fortuitous by selecting all six winning lotto numbers.
example2: Isn’t it quite fortuitous the stolen money reappeared before the police arrived?

title: Obnoxious
definition: Extremely unpleasant
example1: He said some really obnoxious things about his ex-girlfriend at the party.
example2: Some teenagers were being loud and obnoxious.

title: Litigious
definition: Tending or too ready to take legal action to settle disputes.
example1: In today's litigious society, even small mishaps can result in large lawsuits.
example2: Overall, it's been a pretty litigious couple of years.

title: Credence
definition: Belief in or acceptance of something as true.
example1: What we see seems to add credence to the results achieved earlier.
example2: Nobody in the courtroom gave any credence to the drunk’s testimony.
